Mr. President, on behalf of the Socialist Group, I would like to express the most energetic repulsion of my group to the murders that are being committed in this region of Somalia, invoking the name of God.
Few atrocities have been committed by someone who has not invoked the name of God or a religion.

Specifically, the way this atrocious murder was committed, we already know, a thirteen-year-old girl who is raped and then accused of adultery, and that five men, if they can be called men, rush to stone her and even prevent someone from trying to save her in a stadium occupied by a thousand people.
This, combined with the acts of piracy that this year on the coasts of Somalia have reached the level of almost 100 ships, constitutes an absolutely unacceptable humanitarian situation.
The international community cannot remain impassive in the face of this.
It cannot remain impassive in the face of cowardice, in the face of religious invocation to commit barbarities.
Por tanto, tenemos que restablecer el orden apoyando al gobierno legítimo de Somalia a recuperar el control de todo el país y a establecer un estado de derecho que respete los derechos humanos.
I believe that on few occasions we have been presented with such a clear situation and that imposes obligations on us.
I do not believe that we can stand idly by in this community of five hundred million people and twenty-seven countries, the most important in the world, without intervening in this situation.

Mr. President, in the EU there are several cases of languages of historical European peoples that, because they are not constituted in states, are not allowed to be used in the debates of this Parliament, and this is a democratic and representative deficit.

One of these cases is that of the Basque language, Euskera, which is not a minority language but an official one, at least in the southern part of the Basque Country, which is administratively part of the Spanish state.

But the same does not happen and do not take it as something personal, Mr. Commissioner, with the Basque Country of the North, attached to the French State, whose president, before the UN Assembly, affirms that denying respect to national identities and languages is feeding humiliation and that without that respect there will be no peace in the world.
And then neither Basque, nor Corsican, Breton, or Occitan have the slightest official consideration and do not have support to respect and promote their use.

Por ello, yo pido que la Agencia de los Derechos Fundamentales, vela y trabaje para que en el interior de los Estados miembros no se violen los derechos de la lengua materna de ningún pueblo europeo, ni se discrimine a sus habitantes y que todas ellas sean consideradas oficiales dentro de sus respectivos territorios.

Thank you, Madam President. First of all, I would like to thank our rapporteur, Claudio Fava, for his great work in reaching a common position with the Council, which includes many improvements proposed by our House.
With this directive, we demonstrate once again our commitment to the construction of a common migration policy based on a global approach.
The aim of this directive is clear: to fight against mafias, punish unscrupulous employers, and protect exploited immigrants who have no social protection.

We want the unjust and miserable wages for immigrants to disappear, and that they also disperse the average salaries, especially in sectors such as construction, agriculture, domestic service or hospitality.
These measures require great courage and political will, since there are many vested interests and a lot of money that moves in the shadow economy.
Precisamente en tiempos difíciles es más importante que nunca gestionar con inteligencia los flujos migratorios con generosidad, pero con responsabilidad.
It would be easy to fall into the temptation of not trying to revive the submerged economy.
We cannot turn a blind eye and leave about eight million irregular immigrants in a situation of defenselessness with working conditions close to slavery.

Ladies and gentlemen, if we want this directive to be effective, rigorous inspections and economic and even criminal sanctions in the most serious cases are necessary, which have a deterrent effect on businesses.
We will thus be able to reduce the pool of the submerged economy and cut the migratory incentive that generates the possibility of working irregularly.
It must be clear that the only option for working in Europe is the legal way.

Therefore, we want to move forward with the global approach and we ask the Commission, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Barrot, to present as soon as possible the new blue cards in quotation marks for the other categories of work.
Dear colleagues, Mrs. Ferrero-Waldner, Mr. Solana, I would like to thank the three rapporteurs for their work, and in the meantime, I will refer to the shadow report on fishing.
To this report in particular, starting by congratulating Mr. Sarybowski on the result of his work and on the collaboration that he has offered from the other groups to achieve a consensual result.

In the same way that this Parliament has repeatedly demanded that the European Union be equipped with the necessary instruments to speak with a single voice in the world, the House itself knows how to show cohesion around the evaluation and the momentum of the major priorities in foreign policy and common security.

The commitment of our group, the Socialist Group, has gone in a double direction, on the one hand, to introduce or reinforce major issues that are key to us in a transversal way to all foreign policy, such as the fight against climate change, the promotion of

Peace throughout the planet or a commitment to human development. On the other hand, propose elements of rebalancing between the geographical priorities of the PESC, as they appeared originally in the text, if they appeared, or introduce them as new elements, if they were absent.

In this way, we have advocated, for example, for greater clarification of the relations between the institutional frameworks and cooperation mechanisms involved in the recently defined eastern dimension.

We have defended greater diversification and greater relevance of relations with Africa, a continent of which we often only remember when wars of special virulence occur, and many times not even that.

Regarding Latin America, we have wanted the current processes of negotiation of association agreements, the first of a bilateral nature, to be reflected, which will conclude the European Union in its entire history.

Regarding the Mediterranean, we have opposed a reductionist approximation that only speaks of security to include, instead, the entire rich political, economic, and sociocultural heritage contained in the Barcelona process.

Regarding amendments for the plenary, our group has not presented any, believing that in some way it reinforces the balance achieved with the commitments and, therefore, we are going to oppose the majority of the amendments in order not to weaken the commitment achieved in the Foreign Affairs Commission. Thank you.

That our representatives make statements during their visits to third countries that violate local legislation and, even less, that insult a head of state, no matter how critical he may be.

Council of May 28, 2001, on cooperation between the judicial bodies of the Member States in the field of obtaining evidence in civil or commercial matters.

We are in a field that is really not a community field, it is an intergovernmental field in which, from the Council, through the regulation, cooperation between those judicial bodies has been stimulated.
But in doing so, I believe that there is a certain lack of rigor on the part of the European Union.

That is to say, certain measures have been planned, such as the issuance of practical guides, the use of electronic media, etc. But I recognize that it is quite difficult for the Commission to take action.
I do not know what the Commission has achieved or plans to achieve, but it seems quite difficult to achieve it given the enormous difficulty of this form of intergovernmental cooperation.

In other words, we are asking the judicial authorities to collaborate with each other. We are talking about twenty seven countries, judicial authorities that handle twenty two different languages, with very different legal systems among themselves, and we are trying to achieve results.
The Commission has found that the results are not good, that there is a huge delay in these cooperation mechanisms, and of course that we do not have the means to do so.
The ideal would be to have material means.
For example, what could the Commission do to equip the judicial bodies, especially those at a lower level, with technological elements such as a video conferencing system?
Video conferencing can be a utopia in many small courts of the European Union as a whole, but it seems to be the only way to do it.
I believe that the European Union should rely on existing institutions, specifically the European judicial network.
We should strengthen this institution so that the judges themselves, through their cooperation systems, could develop this type of communication.
On the other hand, any training of judges is essential.
This is something that the Commission cannot do on its own.
Pero sí puede la Comisión estimular el desarrollo de este tipo de cursos de formación en Derecho comunitario y en el conocimiento de los diferentes sistemas jurídicos.
Then there is a huge difficulty, which is the problem of languages, that is, how can we communicate? Let's put a Spanish judge with a Finnish judge with two such different languages.
You can not expect judges, in addition to having to handle their own right, which is already quite complex in itself, to be obliged to have knowledge for this type of.
What can we do from a practical point of view to facilitate judges' interpretation and translation tasks?
Translation: What could we do to help them do it?
In presenting this report, I will not show any kind of rigor or harshness towards the Commission.
Creo que el trabajo es bastante difícil.

I am very strict with this 2001 regulation, a little imprecise, a little voluntarist, and I do not know if, from a practical point of view, it can have any consequences or if it can be advanced with it.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I am very happy to be able to conclude the present legislature with the definitive approval of the last of the maritime packages.

However, I remember that when I arrived at the European Parliament in 1999, we suffered a major maritime accident, that of the Erika ship, off the French coast, which gave rise to a first block of legislative proposals aimed at preventing and avoiding accidents.
We thought we had conjured up the danger, but shortly after the coasts of Galicia were ruined by the chapapote, resulting from another accident even greater than the first, that of the

Since then, in the Transport Committee, we have worked on successive legislative packages, trying to overcome the excessive resistance we encountered in shippers, oil companies, classification societies, and also in certain Member States that rejected our proposals for considering them too demanding.

In these ten years, we have approved different directives and regulations, some of which we had to review again because, due to the cuts made by the Council, they were not effective in their first draft.

We approve the standards for the introduction of double-hulled ships, the European Fund for Major Oil Spill Catastrophes, ports of refuge, and now we review and approve the responsibility of passenger ship carriers, the investigation of accidents.

Maritime accidents, the Community system for monitoring and information on maritime traffic, the control by the port state, and finally, the regulations and directives concerning the organizations for the inspection and recognition of ships.
And all this is good and desirable, that it can come into force and be applied by all Member States in the shortest possible time frame.
Por ello me siento satisfecho.
Pero acaba la legislatura, yo dejo el Parlamento y me voy con la pena de no haber conseguido que se estableciera como obligatorio la introducción de sistemas de control que existen.
Se están patentando para saber cuándo y cuántos residuos de centinas y tanques de fuel se han vertido al mar ilegalmente por parte de un determinado buque.
That is to say, a kind of black boxes or tachometers that can be inspected by the maritime authorities every time a ship arrives at port.

I believe that we owe the marine environment not only better attention and more severe procedures to curb the pollution we produce, but also that if we do not do so, it will affect our food chain and our lives, making us pay a high price.
I trust that they will not have to wait another ten years to more effectively and efficiently control illegal sea dumping.
President, the review of the Euroviñeta directive is a matter of great importance that concerns and worries us all, especially the peripheral countries that feel victimized by this proposal.
The European Commission has decided to address the internalization of external costs of road transport, by imposing three new costs, air pollution, noise pollution and congestion.

Although the principles that inspire the proposal, who uses, pays and who pollutes, pay are reasonable, the solution that is proposed is not reasonable at all, as it will be discriminatory for a sector that has been suffering for months the disastrous effects of the economic crisis.
Demonizing the transport of goods by road, even if it was not the objective, has resulted in being the end.

This proposal, ladies and gentlemen, is untimely and far from achieving the expected objectives of sustainable transport. It would be the death sentence for a large number of small and medium-sized European companies that employ thousands of people.

Personas en la Unión Europea que contribuyen diariamente a la distribución de mercancías, asegurando que los productos lleguen a su consumidor final, un consumidor que verá cómo sus productos se encarecen por la aplicación de estas tasas.
Ladies and gentlemen, we need a competitive, sustainable and environmentally friendly transport system, without ignoring the road, because it is currently the only way to reach all parts.
The modal change is still a dream, far from being a reality.
The trans-European networks, the sea highways, the cross-border connections continue to be, in some cases, projects and not reality.
Ladies and gentlemen, when the Titanic of the global economy sinks, it is not possible to ask the orchestra to keep playing, much less for joy.

Thank you, Mr. President. On July 15, 2008, the European Commission adopted a communication addressed to the Council and the Parliament, recommending the establishment of a strategic association between the European Union and Mexico.
On its part, the European Council of Foreign Affairs, on October 13th, recognized Mexico as a strategic partner, waiting for the opinion of the Parliament on the matter.
Let us remember that in the seventh meeting of the Mixed Parliamentary Commission of the European Union and Mexico, held at the end of October last year, we said that one.
This strategic association between Mexico and the European Union constitutes a necessary impulse to strengthen and develop the true potential of our bilateral relations.
We highlight the good moment of the relations between both parties and the positive balance of the current global agreement.

We insist on the need for our respective executives to strengthen collaboration in political, economic and cooperation matters to the maximum in the face of the new challenges of all kinds derived from the financial and economic crisis that is shaking our continents.

With the great country that is Mexico, we share values and objectives such as the development of democratic forms of government, commitment to gender equality, consolidation of the rule of law, equitable and sustainable development, and respect for human rights.
We advocate for narrowing cooperation in the fight against organized crime, terrorism, and drug trafficking based on the principles of shared responsibility and strict adherence to international law.
As a result, we will support the proposal for recommendations on the strategic association between the European Union and Mexico, which will be submitted to Parliament this morning.
I would like to congratulate all the speakers on the microcredit report, because they have done a great job.

Which has been a success in many developing countries, including some European ones, both as a mechanism for economic activity and as an instrument for improving social inclusion and job creation.
But it had not been transferred to the sector or the community context, and I believe it is an opportunity to do so, especially by starting from the economic and financial context in which we are.
Priority in that sense is to reinforce the initiatives that are being advanced here, but more steps must be taken.
We must increase the funds available for this microcredit support structure.
Hay que facilitar la disponibilidad para las personas y las empresas que no tienen acceso a los préstamos y en ese sentido quisiera destacar, presidenta, el ejemplo de.
Es la garantía europea para préstamos de microcréditos como un instrumento que puede facilitar ese acceso y que se ha incluido en el informe.
And I end thinking that, without a doubt, this will lay the foundations for us to create an arm's length framework in the European context that will drive the microcredit sector.

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. This question, as Mr. Bockland has explained, is very timely given the diplomatic conference on the Convention on the Recycling of Ships that is going to be held in May.
Therefore, I would like to congratulate Mr. Blok on not only the question, but also on the resolution he has prepared.

En el Partido Popular estamos a favor de la lucha contra las malas prácticas y métodos que se vienen empleando para desguazar los buques y, por lo tanto, apoyamos la propuesta de resolución del señor Brokland. Pero hay algunos puntos que nos preocupan.

The first is paragraph 3, which he has also pointed out, which states that ships in their entirety must be considered dangerous waste and, as a consequence, must be within the scope of application of the Basel Convention.

We have presented an amendment on this section because there are different interpretations within and outside the European Union, and we understand that the Basel Convention must be taken into account and not be in contradiction with it, but it should be the future international agreement on shipbreaking that defines the details of its application.
The resolution proposal also requests, in its point fourteen, a financing mechanism based on mandatory contributions from the maritime transport sector.

It seems a bit hasty to talk about mandatory contributions at this time, when the OMC has not yet decided what system will be adopted for this financing, and it seems that the European Commission does not have a clear answer on this matter.
Finally, in point 15, the Commission is instructed to clearly establish that the state with jurisdiction over waste is the responsible state.
We believe that it is the competence of the Commission to decide this, which should also be decided in an international agreement.

The important thing is to ensure coherence on the future agreement on the recycling of waste containers and the Basel Convention on the transboundary control of hazardous waste and its disposal, taking into account not only the Basel Convention but all existing legislation.

Thank you, Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the first thing I would like to do is congratulate the speaker with whom we share a great coincidence regarding this program and congratulate us all because in a time of economic crisis it is essential to maintain a program like this with clear positive social effects.

Although we are before a procedure of inquiry from the European Parliament, we must send a clear political signal that in these moments of economic uncertainty from Brussels and Strasbourg, we are not exclusively concerned.

Not only concerned about a recovery of the financial system, but we are fully aware that social policies, especially those that support those who need it most, the poorest in the European Union, have to grow.

This food distribution program must continue to be considered part of the common agricultural policy. We agree with the Commission on this, because European agriculture has a marked social character, because it is an instrument that works, because it is needed more than ever now, and because it must continue to function.

From the Socialist Group, like the spokesperson, we are opposed to this program being co-financed between the European Union and the Member States, as this would mean discrimination between states according to their wealth, and it could happen that the program cannot be implemented in the most needy countries.

It is not understood that now, when it is most needed, the Commission wants to save Community money in the most social aspect of the PAC, especially considering that in every year there are budgetary surpluses in the agricultural budget.
Full community funding is essential for us.
We need to ensure that this program reaches all countries and, above all, the most needy.
Forty three million potential beneficiaries of this program demand greater effort and in no case should budgetary expenditure be spared.
Austerity, yes, but not with the poorest.
And it is precisely to ensure that the citizen of all member states receives it that the program must cover the entire distribution route of the food.

Therefore, from the Socialist Group, for which I am responsible for the report, we have tabled an amendment to ensure that all expenses related to distribution, including those for transportation, storage, and administration, are covered by Community funds.
We also agree with the speaker that food should be preferably community-based and of quality.

It is the consistent position with that maintained by this parliament in other similar programs that we recently discussed in this chamber, as was the case with the fruit distribution plan in schools.
Nothing more and thank you very much.
We hope that the Commission will take into account the position of this Parliament when it votes and, above all, that the plan will be put into action in the European Union as soon as possible.
The Arctic region is one of the most fragile regions of our planet.
The consequences of an unrestricted exploitation of its natural resources would be catastrophic, not only for the immediate environment and the indigenous population, but for the world as a whole.

The thawing of large areas has made these risks current, with which a new global regulation is necessary to protect the Arctic, similar to the one that already exists for the Antarctic, while taking into account the differences that have already emerged in the debate.

It is necessary an international treaty between all the parties involved, among which, without a doubt, will be the European Union, to protect its unique environment, ensure the fully sustainable character of all types of human activities, and regulate multilaterally the navigation through the new maritime routes that are made accessible.
The Arctic Council, during its several years of existence, has been a model of cooperation to manage common problems.

In these moments of difficulty and uncertainty, we must bring to the fore that spirit and that harmony to prevent the states of the area or other international actors from settling into geo-strategic pugnacity, forgetting what should be the common objective, the preservation of a great shared heritage.

Yes, Mr. President, the information you give me is correct, but the impression that we European parliamentarians, and ultimately the European citizens, have is that we have a very dangerous gap in the common law.

Madam President, for once I am glad that the titular speaker, Mr Tajani, has not come, because Mr Tajani has the advantage of having been a European parliamentarian.
Y como parlamentario europeo sé que ha experimentado la frustración que tenemos los parlamentarios europeos con respecto a la aplicación del Derecho comunitario.

Now in Parliament we tend to get involved with the Commission. I think we are asking the Commission for an impossible mission, because all Community law and the application of Community law are based on indirect application.

That is to say, the Commission has only a few officials in the central headquarters, where they receive some complaints and have some possibilities of action, but at this moment, the tendency is to limit the budgetary powers, so the Commission will not have the possibility to do so.
All Community law, all the application of Community law, is based on the action of national authorities, national parliaments, national judges, national civil servants.
And here, in this regard, I do not think we can demand too much from the Commission.
What we have to do is help the Commission and I believe that in the report of Mrs. Frazzoni there are some points that can be useful to achieve this application.
I am referring to those related to the correlation of directives, the collaboration of national parliaments, and the action of national courts.
Mr. President, two years ago, on a mission that was led by my colleague from the group here, Marianne, I had the opportunity to visit.
Sierra Leona and to be present in this court and to be aware of the immense work that this court was doing, not only for Sierra Leone but for all humanity.
The Special Court of Sierra Leone, as has already been mentioned here, has certainly set a precedent.

A precedent because, as the resolution indicates, it is the first international funded by voluntary contributions, it is the first tribunal to be created in the country where the alleged crimes took place, and it is also the first tribunal, as already mentioned, in which an ex-prime minister has been tried.

For all of this, not only because it is a precedent, but because it is a reference for other courts that have been created in its wake, such as Rwanda, former Yugoslavia, Cambodia or Lebanon, we consider it essential that this resolution be approved, in which we have been working together with the court for several months.
Hace dos años aprobamos una resolución para apoyar su financiación. Hace dos años, el Tribunal estaba atravesando un período difícil en el cual se estaba quedando sin.
Money and did not have enough support. We must thank the European Commission here, too, for coming out in financial support of this court.

Now we ask for two things above all. First, that the convicted people serve their sentences. The functioning of the court is at stake, not just the court that ends next year, but the legacy that this court will leave us. Second, obviously, all of this must be accompanied by greater funding.
In short, the Special Court for Sierra Leone is an example and a reference for all of us and for all the courts that have judged war crimes.

It is an example and a reference, and it is a lesson that the second poorest country on this planet is giving us, in which, when entering the court, we saw a slogan written that said, without justice, there is no peace.
And precisely for that reason, we have the moral obligation, not only as Europeans, but as human beings, that the legacy of this court remains permanent in history.

Today we are talking about violence in Mexico and it seems normal to me to recognize that Mexican women, indigenous and non-indigenous, are the least protected victims by local and federal authorities.
Mexican women are victims of all forms of violence, from family violence to sexual violence and torture perpetrated by members of the army or police, and even homicide.
Unfortunately, until now, the responses of the Mexican authorities have been ineffective, and that is why there is correct talk of almost absolute impunity.
Our resolution asks the Mexican government to combat femicides, a harsh but correct word when we see that almost all of the murders committed against women remain impunity.
An example in the state of Mexico, in the last four years, only eleven percent of the criminals who murdered almost seven hundred women were convicted.

In this debate, we have seen clearly that we all agree to support the objective of this report.
The different political groups have shown their support for this directive, which offers greater protection to victims.
Therefore, I wonder what impediment exists to approve this instrument.
I repeat, what fears are there that something as necessary and simple as protecting victims equally throughout Europe will finally become a reality?
"Esperando que este Parlamento apruebe mayoritariamente este informe, me dirijo al Consejo y a la Comisión, recordándoles que hemos."
We have overcome the legal hurdles in our negotiations and I applaud the fact that the Commission recognizes our work as we recognize the work it will do in the future.

We do not have to exclude ourselves, but to help ourselves by approving this more concrete instrument today, and tomorrow the broader package of measures to help the victims that the Commission will present and with which I commit to collaborate.
Therefore, let us be brave and responsible today, and help all those who have the right to live in a safer Europe.
Let's help everyone, I repeat, be it men, women or children.
Let us help those who look at us today so that we can give them a better life, a life that returns their freedom, their security, and above all, their dignity.

Thank you, Madam President. The European People's Party Group will vote on this report enthusiastically. First of all, congratulations to the rapporteurs, the Commission and the Council for this agreement.
We coined, ladies and gentlemen, in the 1980s, the term democratic deficit.
With it, we meant that in the European Union, the decisions were made only by the Council of Ministers on the proposal of the Commission, and this Parliament was only consulted.
La batalla de este parlamento desde los años ochenta, a través del Tratado de Maastricht, de Ámsterdam, de Niza, del Tratado Constitucional, del Tratado de Lisboa, ha sido.

Fill that democratic deficit. And I believe that with the Lisbon Treaty, with the new powers of the European Parliament, with the participation of the national parliaments, we have achieved that objective.
And we round it off today with this citizen legislative initiative, which was due to the good cooperation between national parliaments and the European Parliament in the Convention's work.
Y quiero recordar aquí los nombres de Jurgem Meyer, nuestro colega socialdemócrata alemán, y Ananlam Asur, que fueron los que llevaron esa iniciativa al Pnoconvencion y que hicieron que se aprobara.
Por tanto, creo que completamos el círculo, señora Presidenta.
I believe that today, when we vote on the initiative, we will have brought to the table the act of defunct of the concept of democratic deficit.
It is now up to us, ladies and gentlemen, to act responsibly, and today we also have the opportunity to do so.
By voting on the Union's budget, we will fulfill what is expected of us: a responsible parliament and a co-decisive parliament.
Creo que es un buen día para Europa, señorías.

Thank you, president. In January 2012, four hundred Spanish egg producers could disappear, around thirty percent of the total in my country, with the loss of a production of three hundred thousand tons of eggs.

And the European Union could stop producing those eighty million eggs, those two million tons, and we would only be able to cover them with imports from third countries whose animal welfare standards are much lower than those of the European Union if we do not act with great intelligence.
This directive from 1999, which requires increasing the space in the cages of laying hens, demands that we act with intelligence and with a possibilist vision, because otherwise.

We will only be able to weaken European production and give extra opportunities, commercial opportunities, to third countries where the space per bird is infinitely worse than the current one we have in the European Union.

It is a directive that requires a lot of effort from European producers. Only in Spain can we understand that the cost rises by about six hundred million euros, but we must not forget that it has an economic impact that extends to the livestock industry and the food industry in general.

I therefore ask for the support of your Lordships to the amendment of the Popular Group to paragraph two, where it is requested to seek a solution, at least, for the responsible industrial operations that are undergoing the transformation of their operations and that in January 2012 will be almost finished.

We must support them to transform those facilities and give them time to complete that process, thus avoiding irreparable damage to the farms and preventing a situation of shortage in the community market overnight, consequently increasing prices for the consumer.
It is about respecting the directive to give an opportunity to the egg and egg product industry, while also respecting the right of animal welfare and the right of consumers to a reasonable price.

Thank you, Mr. President. I think it is only fair to thank the rapporteurs, especially Mrs. Grosset and Mrs. Dragmar Rommeren from my own group, for the work they have done to create a standard for stagnation and make it useful, because that work has allowed the right to public health to be included as a legal basis.

And to have a new orientation that allows us to lay the foundations that must guarantee citizens the security and quality they choose at any time, especially because it also allows for the clear regulation of the role of states, both those of origin that have to make the payment and those in which treatment is received.

But I believe that we should not be satisfied with that alone, but that this should be the beginning of a much greater progress that, as Ms. Romweger said, makes this directive a mere formality, because the level of equality achieved in all states makes unnecessary the displacement of each citizen to each country.

And in that struggle, we must obtain a standard that guarantees more the right of citizens in relation to the attention they have to receive, services, safety and security, than the mere right they already have to mobility between states.
Equality is what will make the Union, and if not, we will be taking very small steps.
The Spanish Socialist delegation voted in favor, like the rest of our group, but I would not leave here without expressing my concern because it has been included in this directive.
The issue of organ transplants, contrary to the criterion that the Commission for the Environment had as a result of a permanent stalling of the Council to include transplants in this directive.

I hope that this inclusion does not diminish the effectiveness of the good legislation that we approved in this same plenary, both with the transplant directive and with the action plan, very recently, and with a practical totality of support.

And I warn that we will be vigilant to ensure that the good work done by such successful organizations as the Spanish National Transplant Organization is not undermined by this inclusion, and of course, with that claim of saving twenty thousand lives that we had both in the transplant directive and in the action plan that, I repeat, we approved here.
Por tanto, lo dejo manifiesto y digo que seguiremos atentos al cumplimiento de esta Directiva en ese aspecto.
Thank you, Mr. President. Today is also the European Day against Sexual Health.
Ladies and gentlemen, the data is concerning. The World Health Organization estimates that more than three hundred million people annually involuntarily contract a sexually transmitted disease.

In Europe, as the European Sexual Health Forum warns, the number of unwanted pregnancies among adolescents is a cause for concern due to an excessive deficit of education and information among our young people.

Even as the Commission points out, there are different and diverse inequalities in access to sexual health services in Europe, depending on the states and within these, depending on the level of income of the citizens.
To combat all of this, a European strategy is necessary.
Only in five member states are there plans in this regard, but in all of them, the number of unwanted pregnancies, sexually transmitted diseases, and also the number of abortions have been reduced.
A common strategy that bets on prevention from the educational field, that expands information policies, that increases efforts in family planning and facilitates access to contraceptive methods.
A transversal and ambitious strategy, free of taboos, to guarantee the rights of every citizen to sexual health in the best conditions of safety and health.
In the context of strong social tensions, it is essential to greet with enthusiasm the great social concertation agreement in Spain between the government, the unions, and the employers.
This agreement is exemplary for Europe, where for a long time there have not been such events.

Taking into account also the reasoning of Candido Mendez, one of the main protagonists of that Spanish pact, who on the past Tuesday, February 8th, attended in Brussels the meeting of the Economic and Social Council.
Cándido insistió entonces en la necesidad de extender la concertación a escala europea y en la necesidad de contar con la voz y las iniciativas sindicales en esta Europa nuestra.
"Así debe ser."

Thank you, Mr. President. Saving the distance in matters of terrorism and immigration, I have found that the European Union unfortunately moves in response to emergency situations, such as a serious attack.
An attack or a massive landing of immigrants like the one currently happening in Lampedusa, where the exodus of citizens from Tunisia to the Italian coast can lead to a chronicle of announced deaths.

The journey of hope can end in a cursed journey and will weigh on our consciences, on that of all those who witness these continuous uncontrolled flows, and we do not say enough with sufficient authority.
When it happens, we will take our hand to our head, but the next day we will forget.

European citizens have the obligation and the right to know the truth that the Mediterranean strategy does not work, that the common migration policy will remain a dream as long as European countries do not commit to sufficient economic means to make Frontex effective.
Talking doesn't cost anything, but we have to act.
Do you really think that Frontex can guarantee the security of the European borders today?
Yo creo que no.

And let us hope that the citizens of Tunisia, Egypt, and other Maghreb countries do not decide en masse to seek a better future in Europe and do so in their countries, because they have fought for that and we should contribute to helping them.
Therefore, solidarity, responsibility, but above all, truth, when discussing a European migration policy, which is now more necessary than ever.

Madam President, it has been said already, the backbone of the pension systems in Europe is and must continue to be the public system, because it is the only system that guarantees cohesion and the only one that also reduces the risk of poverty in our society.

It is still alarming that in OECD countries, the highest rates of income inequality among citizens occur in the field of pensions, or that due to the crisis, private pensions lost only twenty percent of their value in 2008 and still remain far from the required solvency levels today.

All of this demonstrates that, in a moment of ineluctable reforms, the sustainability of our pension system must be done in a transversal way, taking into account, among other factors, ambitious policies of birth or work-life balance.
Ambitious policies on access and permanence in employment, or even immigration policies based on integration that also guarantee, from a demographic point of view, the sustainability of our pensions.
Finally, I am sorry that the text does not set limits on the abuse of the figure of scholarships in companies, since, as a general rule, these are excluded from all types of social contributions.

In my opinion, this is essential for a whole new generation of workers to whom, if more is being demanded to have a decent pension, it would also be necessary to make them suffer less to access decent work.

President, Commissioner, we are at a crucial moment in the construction of the future cohesion policy, which, after the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, focuses not only on economic and social aspects, but also on the territorial.
Territorial cohesion pursues harmonious development among territories to enable their citizens to make the most of their territorial peculiarities.
But to achieve this objective, it is also necessary to advance in the field of cooperation between the regions of the Union that face the same challenges and problems.

This is the objective pursued by the European Union's strategy for the Atlantic region, a common perspective to address the common challenges faced by the states of the region, including maritime research, maritime surveillance, and environmental and economic challenges.

To achieve our objectives, it is necessary to adopt an integrated strategic approach that is in tune with the 2020 strategy and the policies of the European Union for the period after 2013, especially with the regional policy and the maritime policy.
But, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, it is necessary that this strategy be based on a renewed multi-level governance based on a closer participation of public authorities.
Regional and local, the Member States, the European Union, and the interested parties of the private sector and civil society organizations, including interregional organizations and networks.

It is a very significant day to talk about equality between men and women, because we celebrate International Women's Day, remembering those who fought a hundred years ago for labor and economic rights and for women's suffrage.
We have made a lot of progress in these 100 years, but there is still much to do and true equality is still a dream, and discrimination against women is a real fact.

I believe that each one of us, men and women, can do much more to achieve the true emancipation of women, because there are many women in the world whose right to live is threatened, their dignity violated and their freedom denied.
Allow me to express my support and hope to all the women who are fighting for their democratic rights in the North African revolution on this day of women.
Because a woman cannot be worth half of a man, neither in Arab countries nor anywhere in the world.
Por tanto, valemos lo mismo y merecemos lo mismo.
And I will continue to fight to achieve it, and as long as that equality does not exist, the day of the woman will continue to exist.
Although many do not want to see it, it is a reality that there are women who earn half as much as men, that domestic violence affects especially women and children.
And I repeat, we must continue to denounce in this Parliament all these facts, and of course, I promise that I will continue working.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to express my agreement with the opinion of the Members who have spoken this morning here and who insist on respect for Parliament and the Commission.
Therefore, my modest affirmative vote will depend on the European Council being willing to admit the role of the mentioned institutions.
Because the new mechanism we are talking about must be an important component of the economic government led by a European Union.
Capable of ensuring the coherence between the common economic policy, which must set clear, precise and limited objectives, and this stability instrument.

In other words, it must be avoided at all costs that this effort in which we are engaged ends up on the intergovernmental path, which is a dead end or the path of the predominance of a few states, because all of this would frustrate the reform.
Dear colleagues, Europe is built stone by stone, and this is one of those that reinforce and balance this delicate building.
There are essential points to improve, so we have to send the report back to the Commission.
This parliamentary report does not end here.
The initial proposal was bad.
This is what consumer associations at the national and European level told us.
And especially my esteem for the work of the Union of Consumers of Asturias and its president, the tireless Dacia Alonso.
We have managed to reject the general principle of maximum harmonization of the old article four.

It must be said very loudly that maximum harmonization by establishing the same protection in all Member States would mean a reduction in the protection of many consumers, as there is a greater tradition in the protection of consumer rights in various countries.

I would like to emphasize, in any case, that it is essential to ensure that the list of abusive contractual clauses is not exhaustive, so that each Member State can increase the number of clauses that it considers unacceptable and invalid in contracts with consumers.

Invierta la carga de la prueba en las cláusulas individuales, por lo que son los comerciantes los que tienen que demostrar que se han negociado individualmente las cláusulas que se alejan de lo generalmente establecido, que las cláusulas contractuales han de estar expresadas de una forma clara y comprensible.
We continue to oppose the establishment of maximum harmonization in relation to abusive clauses.
The Eurobarometer indicates that 79% of traders believe that full harmonization in this field will have little or no effect on their activities abroad.
Thank you, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, first of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr. Schwab and Ms. Gerhart, for the excellent work they have done.
Y una reflexión general.
It is not that protectionism is increased, but rather that it is a question of not cutting rights already existing in some Member States.
Because if we want and pursue to establish a real internal market for relations between companies and consumers, we must.
Establish, in parallel, a balance between the high level of protection of consumer rights and the defense of the competitiveness of companies.
This balance involves agreeing on a minimum harmonization and the possibility of allowing Member States to maintain or adopt additional regulations that improve consumer protection.
We cannot allow the adoption of a Community standard to result in the unprotected status of many consumers and users.
I celebrate that the negotiations in the European Parliament have improved, but I would like to insist that the rights that are already established are not cut.

Thank you, Mr. President. Many experts are telling us that the next crisis may be energy-related, and that, moreover, either we are not doing the necessary duties to prevent it, or we are not doing it at the necessary speed to prevent it.
This coming Saturday, the World Forum for Nature calls for everyone to make a small gesture in the name of sustainability.
Many citizens will turn off the lights for an hour and many public administrations will follow suit.
Pero no es suficiente.
Europe cannot continue to depend on energies that are not its own, that are far away, or on insecure energies.
We have to help states to build a new energy model in which renewable energies are the heart of the new model.
And we must also support the awareness of new consumption patterns, because without a doubt, renewables and efficiency are the keys to future sustainability.

Finally, I want to make a call to all the countries of the Union to join that call, to that will of five states, including Spain, to increase CO2 emission reductions to thirty percent, because that way we would demonstrate that Europe, in addition to being a vanguard of freedom and rights, is also a vanguard of its commitment to the sustainability of the planet.
Thank you very much. Most of the times I have spoken in this Parliament, I have done so to denounce violence against women, and I am here again to fight it.

I must say that not only do I not get tired of it, but I consider it essential to continue speaking publicly about this violation of human rights, since there is no cause that can be defended without a resonating box, and this parliament is the best.

I have the platform available to defend all those women who suffer daily abuse and who need us legislators to force states to punish aggressors according to the severity of the crime and also to help victims.

When it is estimated that a quarter of European women have experienced gender-based violence at least once in their lives, and that children to the same extent, I believe it is impossible not to demand a greater commitment, as recognized by the Commission in its action plan.

I believe it is necessary to continue insisting, again and again, to weave the victims, as we did in the European Victims' Protection Order, of which I was a spokesperson and which I hope will become a reality as soon as possible.
Este informe ha contado con un gran consenso y apoyo desde el inicio, lo que demuestra que cuando se trata de abordar la violencia doméstica que afecta a todos los miembros de la familia.
Family, children, elderly, women and men should not be a reason for political opportunism, as it is an honor for all of us to advance in solving this social problem.

The first thing is not to remain silent, and the second is to start working, since although we have been talking about gender-based violence for decades, we have not been able to reduce the number of deaths.
We are doing something wrong and therefore it is time to forget about demagoguery and to move from words to actions, providing more necessary help so that women can live with dignity and security.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. Thank you very much, Commissioner. I agree with you that we must listen to citizens and regain confidence in the European project.
That is why today can be a great day for Europe and European social construction.

Because with the approval of these reports, we not only advance towards the reactivation of the single market, a key element in the face of the current economic crisis, but also respond to the demands of citizens who call for moving towards a more Europe and strengthening social rights.

Europe must respond to the new global challenges and achieve that the European economy becomes a highly competitive social market economy that creates sensitive growth with more and better employment.

But this objective must be based on the inclusion of a social clause in all legislation related to the internal market, which puts citizens at the center of our attention and priority, and strengthens their social rights.
Finally, I would like to ask the Commission to present these proposals as soon as possible.
Mr. President, the blue tongue has been a constant threat to our livestock and, with it, also to our public health.

A disease against which we were fighting through the activated vaccine, whose use entails the creation of restricted areas for the circulation of animals, because the use of these vaccines can cause an undesired circulation of the virus in uninfected animals.

For these reasons, the use of the vaccine was limited to those areas where animals had previously been found infected, creating a double harm for the farmers, on the one hand, the disease and, on the other hand, the restrictions.

But all these problems seem to be avoidable through the new inactivated vaccine, which, in addition to avoiding the disruptions that can occur in the domestic cattle market, allows for the development of new and broader strategies than the truly important one of prevention in the fight against this disease.
For all this reason, it is of vital importance for this sector that we modify the directive to allow its use, and that we do so as soon as possible.

Ladies and gentlemen, the fulfillment of what our treaties provide, especially regarding the correspondence tables, cannot be an excuse for this regulation not to come into force before the summer, because with our delay, with your delay, we would only be harming the breeders.

Thank you, Mr. President. First of all, I would like to thank the Committee on Petitions for the work it has done following the complaint filed by Fepex, the Spanish organization of fruit and vegetable producers and exporters, based on the report published in 2007 by OLAF, the European Union's anti-fraud agency.

I think the conclusions of that report are very clear and justify the fact that the European Commission would have already started work a long time ago to clarify the functioning of the input price system with respect to, at least, the tomato sector.

However, the Commission not only has not intervened to solve possible traps that the entry price regulation can give rise to, but has also negotiated a new agricultural agreement with Morocco without having previously resolved the shortcomings of the current import regime.

Ladies and gentlemen, it is about time for the European Commission to take its responsibilities seriously and start investigating where the frauds occur and eventually request the recovery of unpaid customs duties.
I think that a new agreement with Morocco should not be ratified in any way without the details that we have presented having been resolved.

Our objective is not to limit the signing of international agreements, but to ensure that such agreements do not seriously harm the interests of European productions and that the rules signed in those agreements are respected.

Regarding the new agreement with Morocco, the European fruit and vegetable sector only requests guarantees for the effective implementation of the agreed measures, and this is only possible through the reform of the entry price regime.
Until we have a new system of entry prices, we cannot have a new agreement with Morocco.
We will not be able to ratify that agreement that the Commission has already closed.

Furthermore, if it is the responsibility of the Member States to control, it should be demanded of the Member States a significant economic effort. But it is also true that we have been claiming for a long time that there be a European border customs system, on the same model as the one that the United States has to ensure that effective control.

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. Discussing this report in Parliament has been complex, mainly because it involves these measures that require the approval of the World Trade Organization and the preliminary proposal sent by the Commission to Parliament is different from the one sent to Geneva.
We believe that it is necessary to help Pakistan. We understand that exceptional commercial preferences can be granted, provided that the sensitivities of the
European industry and, in a very special way, the textile sector, which in communities such as the Valencian Community in Spain, suffer severely from the consequences of the crisis.

But this report has allowed us to verify that the measures that can be taken within the framework of international trade cannot be treated with the urgency that these acts require, so we should learn for the future.

To help Pakistan, yes, but not with the original proposal of the Commission, since it does not take into account the effects of the European industry in terms of the application deadlines for sensitive products.
If we even delayed the implementation of these measures because they did not coincide with the pending text to be approved by the OMC, we would be out of time.
Por lo tanto, consideramos que es inaceptable mantener esta propuesta y pensamos que tenemos que votar que no.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to begin my speech by congratulating everyone who has made it possible to reach an agreement.

It is an agreement that we should all congratulate ourselves because it affects the daily life of all citizens, but with the constructive spirit that characterizes me, I would like to make some points.
In the first place, I would like to draw attention to the importance of providing precise, relevant, but above all, understandable and uniform information.
For consumers about the components of textile products, exhaustive information will be of no use if citizens are not able to decipher it.
We have achieved a positive, necessary, but not sufficient step. We should move forward more and protect citizens who could become more vulnerable.
Ladies and gentlemen, it is essential to establish a European system of labeling based on body dimensions, because the first thing we encounter when purchasing an item is the size.
Por eso deberíamos ser mucho más ambiciosos y buscar la armonización de tallas.
Mr. President, three notes on the situation created around cucumbers.
I am a grandson of a German and I have a great affection for that country, but it is evident that the German authorities have acted in this case with haste and recklessness.

On the other hand, if we analyze the European action, we warn that the one developed by the Food Safety Authority and by the Commission has been disjointed, very dim, and imprecise. It has not known how to coordinate or lead.
Third, those affected are entitled to economic compensation quickly.
But for the moment, I propose to this Parliament that we organize in Brussels or here in Strasbourg a great example of European gastronomy based precisely on the cucumber.
We must reclaim the lost honor, a phrase borrowed from the German writer Heinrich Böll. We must reclaim the lost honor of the cucumber producers.
Europa es el escenario adecuado para ello.
Mr President, the first thing is to make a sincere effort to remember the twenty three victims who have already died, twenty two in Germany and one in Sweden.
And this crisis must be said to be the most striking proof that the European Union must improve, and a lot, its food alert system and its internal coordination.
The member states involved have shown slowness, inefficiency, and inaction, and at this point, after twenty-three deaths, we still do not know where the problem comes from.

The European Commission must seriously reflect on the problems caused by its irresponsible actions or inaction in times of crisis, such as the current one, leading to cases of economic ruin, destruction of jobs that were once.

Estables de desempleo, indefensión y, por supuesto, una crisis sanitaria con elevadísimos riesgos de salud de la población. Porque mientras ustedes desde la Comisión se hacían eco de irresponsables declaraciones de autoridades regionales.

German, very uninformed and quite irresponsible, with names and surnames of Spanish farms. Meanwhile, the population was still exposed to the bacteria without knowing it. Believing they were avoiding it, the citizens were more exposed than ever to eating something that could harm them.

The European Commission should today, in the Council of Agriculture, which is held in Luxembourg at 2 p.m., propose to the ministers that part of the 2.5 billion euros that exist as remnants of the common agricultural policy be used.
Those 2.5 billion euros to repair, as much as possible, the damage caused.
To do this, it is necessary to find a legal loophole that allows it. A legal loophole that has already been found on other occasions, such as mad cows or dioxins, and that should now be found.
Therefore, Commissioner, Ministers, today in Luxembourg, you have to live up to your responsibility.

The German authorities, given the irresponsible accusations made, should support this economic solution, without a doubt, and from the beginning, and also fund their own communication campaigns to restore consumer confidence lost in the self-proclaimed fruit productions. Thank you.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, nothing we do here or in the European Union will bring back the lives of the dead, and I hope that what is being done will prevent more deaths and stop the chain of patients suffering without having done anything to be there.

We do not know the causes, surely, but we do know some things that we must call by their name. There has been negligence in political actions and there has been negligence in the German federal government. It cannot act as if Hamburg were a city-state of another continent.

The sovereignty that Mrs. Merkel has and her health minister to address other states with unusual frequency, if it had been translated into diligence and efficiency to coordinate, some of the things that have happened would not have happened.

And that negligence has had criminal consequences on a state that has been the Spanish state and on its most important sector, agriculture, and has led to the ruin of families, thousands of people and small businesses, and has discredited the economy for a long time.
I ask you to go to the Council and ask for full compensation for those affected, since we cannot ask for the lives of the dead.
Y que se revisen los sistemas de control.
Y que se exija responsabilidad a la señora Merkel.
And that less arrogance and more diligence are asked of him.
Y que se haga responsable de los daños que ha causado.
I cannot ignore that Hamburg is in its state.
No puede ignorar sus responsabilidades.
They cannot hide behind a decentralized and federal state to cause the damage they have caused.

A little more humility, a little more good management, and a little less conservatism would have gone very well for this crisis not to escape from their hands, and Spain and other southern farmers would not have had to suffer their painful consequences.
Review the controls, review the alert systems and ask for accountability because in Spain we are asking you, Mr. Commissioner, the Council and the German State.
Mr President, we are facing a public health problem in the face of an epidemic, as the Commissioner has said, and in the face of this, culprits have been sought, if not the cause.

The system has not worked. We have twenty-two deaths, one thousand six hundred affected, and we do not know the cause three weeks later. And appealing to a principle of precaution without scientific basis, I repeat, without scientific basis, Spain is being blamed.
Ladies and gentlemen, the Spanish cucumbers were not contaminated.
Polluted, they were not polluted, I repeat it because some contrary versions have been heard here.
But to show you the importance of what these words have aroused, three hundred thousand jobs can be seen to be affected, a loss of confidence.
Una epidemia no conoce fronteras.

I agree with you, Commissioner. There are no borders. We ask for accountability for what has not been done, for what we must do immediately, because Germany has a risk problem at the moment. It has the highest number of refugees, but Spain is not to blame.
We demand compensation.
Importante y lo que nos une hoy aquí son las víctimas, porque nadie debería sentirse tan desprotegido como hoy nos sentimos los consumidores europeos.
And it is with respect to the victims that we need clarity and responsibility.

And it is my responsibility to denounce the German authorities who unjustly and hastily accused the Spanish cucumbers, and specifically the cooperatives of Malaga and Almeria, which were models of exploitation and will not recover from those accusations.
Thousands of families without jobs wonder why, why they need an answer and above all, what their future will be, not only in Andalusia, but throughout agricultural Europe.

Therefore, and trusting that the experts will quickly find the solution, I demand that when I speak to the Council today, I ask for immediate and moral economic measures for all producers who, from Andalusia and from all of Europe, look at us with indignation but with hope.
Instead of promoting research and European collaboration, the German authorities have slandered and harmed cucumber producers and others.
Y todavía no ha despedido a nadie en Alemania ni ofrecido reparaciones a la altura del daño causado.
It is Germany that has a serious problem of credibility.
The treatment of Mrs. Merkel towards the southern countries in terms of agriculture and also financial is intolerable.
Someone said that Merkel was a disciple of Adenauer and Kohl.
Nada de eso carece de crédito moral.
Thank you, Mr. President. It is not a coincidence that Spain, Italy, Greece, Ireland, Portugal, and other countries share our reluctance to accept the so-called Eurobonds.

The coincidence is the criticism brings cause of our condition of peripheral countries that, in the end, we will be the ones who pay this singular levy that the European Union states that have the geographical center will collect.
The ratio that inspires the Euroviñeta incurs in great contradictions and the supportive discourse becomes more and more weak.

Although the rationality of internalizing external costs is accepted as a starting point, in the end it is not maintained that, in order to alleviate congestion, only large vehicles are penalized, leaving tourism out in the same terms as the old slogan of "who pollutes pays" is applied with obvious discrimination.

On the other hand, ladies and gentlemen, the euro vignette, which was imagined as a source of financing for infrastructure, in the end only fifteen percent will be allocated to the financing of the European networks, and not in a mandatory way.

But as a simple recommendation, in such a way that the Minister of Finance on duty will allocate the collected funds to the purpose that he deems most convenient for the interests of his country, within the broad chapter of infrastructure.
The final result will be nothing but a slap in the face to the transport of goods by road, which today is the only mode that is allowing the domestic market.
This is the reality, ladies and gentlemen, a reality that is much more raw in a context of economic crisis.

In this regard, the competitiveness of European products in the global markets cannot allow experiments that may contribute to further deteriorate the precarious situation of the European economy with the imposition of new added costs.

The food crisis, which has been carelessly brought back on Spanish products, has produced an unjust penalization and huge losses to the same people who are penalized by the euro, small-scale transporters of goods and farmers of crops of the first order.
These are the reasons, ladies and gentlemen, for which the Spanish delegation of the European People's Party will vote against this directive project.

You will all understand, dear colleagues, that by taking the presidency of the session, I express my sorrow and consternation for the death of Jorge Semprun, who passed away a few hours ago at the age of eighty-seven.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen. The current economic and financial crisis that we are experiencing highlights the need for regional policy as the best instrument to reduce the development differences between regions and states.

The future cohesion policy, pillar of solidarity in the European project and social justice, must take into account the following priorities: first, strengthen social cohesion and integrate the challenges posed by the 2020 strategy. Second, take into account the needs and characteristics that.

Geographic regions, especially the most disadvantaged. Third, maintain the principle of graduality in the perception of funds so that the regions do not abandon the objective of convergence, avoiding abrupt changes in the perception of aid. And fourth, promote a system.
Equitativo.

Por ello, el apoyo de la Unión es necesario.
I hope the Council takes note.

In defense of fundamental rights, I ask the responsible institutions to review the designation of San Sebastian as European Capital of Culture, because I believe it has been chosen following a political criterion, which means discrimination against other aspiring cities.

The president of the tribunal said that it was chosen to support the peace process and, as far as I know, in Spain there is a terrorist organization called ETA that, to this day, has not laid down its arms and that two months ago managed to have its political arm, Bildu, govern, among other municipalities, the one of San Sebastian.
I do not believe that from Europe we should give such a powerful megaphone to those who do not condemn terrorist violence and will make propaganda to assign blame between victims and murderers.
Where are the rights to freedom and dignity?
Certainly not in San Sebastian, where our colleagues, such as Mayor Oreja and Turgay, Salva or myself, must be escorted.
Creo en la cultura de la vida, no en la del tiro.
Can there be true culture without freedom?
No, a thousand times no.
When San Sebastian is a free city for all, that it presents its candidacy again, and while they learn the culture of respect for those who think differently.
Because tomorrow they may deserve it, but today, with Batizáurre and his heirs in the institutions, they do not deserve it.

Procedimientos de autorización y licencias en los Estados miembros de asegurando una financiación que atraiga e impulse la inversión privada sin perjuicio de los apoyos públicos que sean necesarios.

Europe to speak with a single voice, a voice that is well heard and resonates in the vault of the European building, because it is from our energy fragility that we have.

Thank you, Mr. President. Every time there is a commitment that allows progress, we must congratulate ourselves, but I do not believe that the commitment we have reached is like dying from a happiness attack.
We must be careful in the happiness raptures we have.

It is true that we have advanced, especially in what concerns the labelling of food, especially in what concerns the security, the clarity of the message, but we have fallen short in trans fats and, for example, in the obligation to label them.
What I do want to ask the Commission is that it does not exhaust the deadlines.

In a continent as well-off as this one, with problems of overnutrition, heart issues, and obesity, we must accelerate and propose as soon as possible the prohibition of adding trans fats to food, as has done Denmark, as is doing Spain, as has done Australia.
Without delay and without further ado.
The commitments will depend on the speed with which we apply, the clarity with which we develop, and the ambition with which we approach.
Let's not dwell on the attack of happiness for what we have done, because it is good, but it is not to jump.
We have to move forward more and be more precise, especially on the issues I have mentioned.
Well, I wanted to tell everyone that there is only one type of terrorism, there is only that terrorism that destroys the lives of innocents, no matter where it comes from.

What the European economy and companies need is confidence.
The audits of accounts are nowadays hampered by the concentration and lack of independence of the auditors and do not contribute to generating the desired trust that boosts our economy.
It would not be inconceivable to consider eliminating the legal obligation of audits.
¿Cuentas por qué no?
If we want to regain the confidence of the markets and in the markets, we must carry out a profound reform of the audits so that they represent a real added value and not a mere legal burden.
The big auditing firms use the auditing services as a presentation card for their future clients.
Once they are familiar with the company, they offer more expensive complementary services with which to often compensate for the low prices of the strict audit.
We have a problem of distortion of prices in the sector.

These complementary services already account for almost fifty percent of the billing, so the large auditors do not want to lose the auditing services, but not for the auditing itself, but for maintaining and increasing the complementary services.
The second major obstacle to free competition in the sector is the oligopoly of the four big ones that dominate the European markets above ninety.
As such, oligopolies control prices and establish barriers to entry for new competitors, relying on intangibles such as the international image of a brand.

It is true that this brand image can be based on certain advantages, but it does not always imply greater efficiency, given the legislative diversity in the accounting states, which are subject to special treatment in each member state.
I share the aims of the Green Book, the independence and concentration of the sector, and the means to use rotation, audits, and joint audits.
Tendering, strengthening of professional skepticism, predominance of substance over form, separation of audit services from non-audit services.

Thank you, Mr. President. I am a councilor of a small town in the center of Spain. And if it is true that the sector represents an opportunity for the European Union as a whole, the tourism sector is much more relevant for the country.
